moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Bg5
comment: I have to make another observation here.  I started playing 6.Bg5 here when I was less than 1400 rated, and my reasons for choosing it had nothing to do with the considerations that might be relavent to me today.  However for a very long time I persisted in playing it exclusively, because it became the only line that I knew, and the disparity grew with every game that I played it again.  I think that this is a common problem in the way that amateurs choose their opening repertoire.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Bg5 e6 7. f4 Be7 8. Qf3 Qa5
comment: This turned out to be a very astute choice as I was much better prepared for the main line.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Bg5 e6 7. f4 Be7 8. Qf3 Qa5 9. Nb3 Qc7 10. Bd3 Nbd7 11. O-O h6 12. Bh4 g5 13. fxg5 Ne5 14. Qe2 Nfg4 15. h3
comment: This fails to even remove the g4-knight, but it does further weaken my dark squares.

comment: With the idea of Nd2-f3. White appears to have made some progress.
